course.description: This course intends to introduce students to basic programming concepts and skills for business data coding and business problem solving. Using Python as an illustrative programming language, this course provides students with a basic understanding of programming concepts and syntaxes, including data types, associated methods and functions, and control flow statements. Through the process of learning a programming language, students will also develop logical and critical thinking skills and be able to tackle simple business problems with coding. For SBM students only.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Clark explicitly said that you could skip the lectures and/or labs if you can handle the content by yourself.

Lectures
I only attended the first lecture and skipped the others.
Prof. Clark explained the material in a very detailed way, so you should be able to understand them if you pay attention in class, but it could be kinda boring cuz the pace is really slow. You may consider learning by YouTube if it's more interesting (and efficient) for you.
He also tried to make the lesson more interactive by asking questions for students to answer (especially those sitting in the back), but it didn't quite work for most of us (me included).

Labs
The lab is for the TAs to help you in case you got any problems with the lab activities. I'm not sure about the arrangement as I never attended any labs, and I don't even know who's the TAs. You could absolutely skip the labs if you can finish the lab activities by yourself, and there's nothing extra to be taught in the lab (from what I was told).
reviews.comment_grading:
4 Weekly Quizzes          20% (5% each)
4 Lab Activities              20% (5% each)
Individual Assignment   10% (up to 5% bonus on top)
Final Exam                     50%

Weekly Quizzes
15 MCs each to check your concepts. Be careful and check your answers before submitting as the scores aren't released until after the deadline, and most people get full marks.

Lab Activities
Write a few lines of code to fulfil the task requirements. They are formatted to guide you to completion, so most people also get full marks.

Individual Assignment
It's like a longer version of the lab activities, with several tasks for you to solve. They give you 2 weeks complete it, and I took ~5 hrs to finish (including lots of checking and refining) and submitted it on day 3. You may want to spread the workload into several days if that's less exhausting for you.
I was never told how the bonus is given, but I guess coding with efficiency and creativity is key.

Final Exam
90 mins to finish 30 MCs, 3 SQs, 2 LQs.
A cheat sheet including almost everything taught in the course is provided, so you only have to understand how it works but not memorize things (which is great for me).
MCs are similar to but somewhat harder than the weekly quizzes.
SQs require you to fill in the blanks in some given codes or ask you about the outputs of the code, basically testing whether you can understand the codes given.
LQs ask you to write code for the tasks. I finished with 15-20 lines of code, so it's not very long, but I suggest checking your own codes several times (if you have time) to search for bugs as it's a PAPER EXAM and you can't rely on the computers.
The paper is longer than I expected. There's sufficient time to finish it for sure, but you can't spend too much time thinking. I actually made quite some mistakes initially, so checking really helps. If you want to spare more time for checking your answers, try responding to the questions instinctively, so practice beforehand is crucial (although I didn't do much). Also, this term is a F2F exam, so the format is likely different from those conducted online during covid.

My scores :
Weekly Quizzes              20/20
Lab Activities                  20/20
Individual Assignment    9.6/10
Final Exam                      45/50

Grade : A+

They didn't release the scores and statistics of the individual assignment and final exam on Canvas, but they'll let you know your own scores if you ask them via email.
I can't really tell how the grading is without the overall statistics, but I guess it's not too bad given that only 90% in the Final Exam (or Overall 94.6%) gets me an A+. The grades are likely proportional to your carefulness and prior experience in programming.
